workflow.name: Digitize business cards with Thai OCR & save to Google Sheets or CRM
workflow.description:
## This n8n template demonstrates how to use Typhoon OCR + LLM to digitize business cards, enrich the extracted details, and save them directly into Google Sheets or any CRM.

It works with both Thai and English business cards and even includes an optional step to draft greeting emails automatically.

Use cases: Automatically capture leads at events, enrich contact details before saving them into your CRM, or simply keep a structured database of your professional network.

### Good to know

Two versions of the workflow are provided:

ðŸŸ¢ **Without Search API** â†’ cost-free option using only Typhoon OCR + LLM

ðŸ”µ **With Search API** â†’ adds Google Search enrichment for richer profiles (may incur API costs via SerpAPI)

The Send Email step is optional â€” include it if you want to follow up instantly, or disable it if not needed.

Typhoon provides a free API for anyone to sign up and use â†’ [opentyphoon.ai](https://opentyphoon.ai/?utm_source=n8n)


### How it works

1. A form submission triggers the workflow with a business card image (JPG/PNG).

2. Typhoon OCR extracts text from the card (supports Thai & English).

3. Typhoon LLM parses the extracted text into structured JSON fields (e.g., name, job title, organization, email).

4. Depending on your chosen path:

- Version 1: Typhoon LLM enriches the record with job type, level, and sector.

- Version 2: The workflow calls the Search API (via SerpAPI) to add a profile/company summary.

5. The cleaned and enriched contact is saved to Google Sheets (can be swapped with your preferred CRM or database).

6. (Optional) Typhoon LLM drafts a short, friendly greeting email, which can be sent automatically via Gmail.

### How to use

The included form trigger is just one example. You can replace it with:
- A webhook for uploads
- A file drop in cloud storage
- Or even a manual trigger for testing

You can easily change the destination from Google Sheets to HubSpot, Notion, Airtable, or Salesforce.

The enrichment prompt is customizable â€” adjust it to classify contacts based on your organizationâ€™s needs.

### Requirements

- Typhoon API key
- Google Sheets API credentials + a prepared spreadsheet
- (Optional) Gmail API credentials for sending emails
- (Optional) SerpAPI key for the Search API enrichment path

### Customising this workflow

This AI-powered business card reader can be adapted to many scenarios:

- Event lead capture: Collect cards at conferences and sync them to your CRM automatically.

- Sales enablement: Draft instant greeting emails for new contacts.

- Networking: Keep a clean and enriched database of your professional connections.

workflow.name: Template_OCR Business Card Reader with Thai Support â€“ Enrich & Save Contacts to CRM Spreadsheet

parameters.content:
## Version 1: Without Search API

1. Trigger â€“ Upload a business card image.

2. Typhoon OCR â€“ Extracts text from the card. Edit Image node prior to this node is needed.

3. Typhoon LLM (Parser) â€“ Converts the raw text into a structured contact fields in JSON format.

4. Typhoon LLM (Enricher) â€“ Adds extra fields such as job type, job level, and sector.

âœ¨ Adjust the prompt here to match your business needs.

5. Typhoon LLM (Email Draft) â€“ Generates a short greeting email (in case needed)

6. Google Sheets â€“ Saves the structured contact information.

7. Optional Email Step â€“ If youâ€™d like to send the greeting email:
- Connect the Text to JSON and Gmail nodes.
- Leave them disconnected if you donâ€™t need this feature.

parameters.text: =Below is an image of a document page, along with its dimensions and possibly some raw textual content previously extracted from it. Note that the text extraction may be incomplete or partially missing. Carefully consider both the layout and any available text to reconstruct the document accurately. Your task is to return the markdown representation of this document, presenting tables in HTML format as they naturally appear. If the document contains images or figures, analyze them and include the tag in the appropriate location. Your final output must be in JSON format with a single key `natural_text` containing the response. RAW_TEXT_START Page dimensions: {{ $json.size.width }}.0x{{ $json.size.height }}.0 [Image 0x0 to {{ $json.size.width }}x{{ $json.size.height }}] RAW_TEXT_END

=Extract the following information from the provided text and format as JSON:

**Text to process:**
{{ $json.output }}

**Required JSON fields:**
- `first_name_en` - First name in English if exists
- `first_name_th` - First name in Thai if exists
- `last_name_en` - Last name in English if exists 
- `last_name_th` - Last name in Thai if exists
- `nick_name_en` - Nick name in English if exists
- `nick_name_th` - Nick name in Thai if exists
- `job_title_en` - Job title in English if exists
- `job_title_th` - Job title in Thai if exists
- `organization_en` - Organization name in English if exists
- `organization_th` - Organization name in Thai if exists
- `email` - Email address
- `phone` - Phone number
- `website` - Website URL

**Instructions:**
- Return only valid JSON without code fences, markdown, or explanatory text
- Use `null` as the value for missing information
- Do not copy `first_name_en` OR `last_name_en` to `first_name_th` OR `last_name_th` name, and vice versa
- If there is a name in parentheses and it is before last name or after last name, you can assume that it is the nick name. Strip out the parenthesis before parsing as nick_name
- Preserve original formatting for names and titles
- If there is a country code for phone number, make sure to remove the plus (+) sign and put the code in parentheses. For example, if the phone number contains +66 you will parse it as (66)
- Remove spaces between numbers in phone number
- Ensure all field names match exactly as specified above

**Expected output format:**
```json
{
  "first_name_en": "value",
  "first_name_th": "value",
  "last_name_en": "value",
  "last_name_th": "value",
  "nick_name_en": "value",
  "nick_name_th": "value",
  "job_title_en": "value", 
  "job_title_th": "value",
  "organization_en": "value",
  "organization_th": "value",
  "email": "value",
  "phone": "value",
  "website": "value"
}
```

messageValues.message:
=You are a smart assistant that extracts contact information from messy text (e.g. OCR results from a business card).  

Instructions: 
- The input text may include either or both English and Thai. Carefully identify the language (Thai or English) for each piece of information.
 - If both English and Thai versions appear, fill both fields.
- If not, fill in only the relevant language fields and use 'null' for missing information
- Only capitalize the first letter of `first_name_en` and `last_name_en` and `nick_name_en`
 - Put the text in the correct language field. For example, if the name is in Thai, fill first_name_th / last_name_th / nick_name_th, and vice versa
- For website, if not explicitly given, just imply it from an email domain. However, you should do so only if the email domain appears to be a company domain, not a free domain like gmail, outlook, etc. Otherwise, just leave it blank.

parameters.text:
=Given this original JSON {{ $json.text }}, your task is to classify and return the following additional fields in JSON:

1. job_type
Possible values: Technical, Business, Both

2. job_level
Possible values: Junior, Senior, Manager/Director, Executive

3. sector
Possible values:
- Consulting / System Integrator
- Academic
- Startup
- Enterprise
- Government

Return only the JSON object. Do not include any code fences or markdown.

messageValues.message: You are an assistant that classifies business contacts into marketing categories. Instructions: - Use job title, organization name, email domain, and website to make the best classification. - Carefully infer the likely job_type from job title. E.g., technical roles like engineer, developer = Technical; sales or marketing = Business; roles blending both = Both - Infer job_level from job title: Junior, Senior, Manager/Director, Executive. - Infer sector from organization name or email domain: Academic for universities or schools; Government for ministries or departments; Startup for small tech companies; Enterprise for large companies; Consulting/System Integrator for consultancies. - If you cannot confidently assign a field, leave it as an empty string.

parameters.text:
=Write a short, friendly greeting email to the person whose name card was collected at an event or a workshop (Techsauce Global Summit 2025) and format the email into a JSON object with two fields:\n
- \"subject\": the email subject\n   
- \"body\": the message content\n\n
You have access to structured data from a name card,{{ $('Text to JSON') .item.json.contact_obj.toJsonString() }}, including the recipientâ€™s first name (which you can use to greet them). Other details may be available but are not guaranteed.
You also have access to the name cardâ€™s owner message that is left when they gave us the name card. {{ $('On form submission').item.json['Message (Optional)'] }}. The email contain should acknowledge the message received and respond with helpful information.
Do not include markdown, explanations, or code blocks. Your email MUST BE IN ENGLISH.
At the end of the email content, also add that this email sender is not an official email and is used for the automation workflow demo purpose only. If the recipient want to contact Typhoon team formally, please send an email or reply back to "contact@opentyphoon.ai"

messageValues.message:
You are a warm, helpful, and professional marketing/community representative from Typhoon. Your task is to write a personalized greeting email based on given information in the user prompt.   Instructions:  1. If `first_name` is available, greet the recipient using it. If not, use a general greeting.
  2. Acknowledge the recent contact (e.g. we received your name card)
  3. Acknowledge the contactâ€™s message or questions if provided in the prompt (optional)
   4. Invite follow-up or continued conversation
  5. Keep it short, clear, and friendly. Do not assume things you donâ€™t know for sure and add too much personalization based on all the fields youâ€™re givena
 6. Email content must be complete. Do not add boilerplate or incomplete content pieces. 7. Return only a valid JSON object with "headline" and "body".

parameters.formDescription: Upload your name card and message (optional) here. We will get back to you soon.

- Use `null` as the value for missing information

- If there is a name in parentheses and it is before last name or after last name, you can assume that it is the nick name. Strip out the parenthesis before parsing as nick_name
- Preserve original formatting for names and titles
- If there is a country code for phone number, make sure to remove the plus (+) sign and put the code in parentheses. For example, if the phone number contains +66 you will parse it as (66)
- Remove spaces between numbers in phone number
- Ensure all field names match exactly as specified above

**Expected output format:**
```json
{
  "first_name_en": "value",
  "first_name_th": "value",
  "last_name_en": "value",
  "last_name_th": "value",
  "nick_name_en": "value",
  "nick_name_th": "value",
  "job_title_en": "value", 
  "job_title_th": "value",
  "organization_en": "value",
  "organization_th": "value",
  "email": "value",
  "phone": "value",
  "website": "value"
}
```

## Version 2: With Search API

1. Trigger: Form submission with name card

2. Typhoon OCR extracts text. Edit Image node prior to this node is needed.

3. Typhoon LLM converts the raw text into a structured contact fields in JSON format.

4. Search API (via SerpAPI) enriches with profile/company info

âœ¨ Adjust the prompt here to match your business needs.

5. Typhoon LLM (Email Draft) â€“ Generates a short greeting email (in case needed)

6. Google Sheets â€“ Saves the structured contact information.

- Connect the Text to JSON and Gmail nodes.

=Given this original JSON {{ $json.text }}, your task is to classify and return the following additional fields in JSON:

1. job_type
Possible values: Technical, Business, Both

2. job_level
Possible values: Junior, Senior, Manager/Director, Executive

3. sector
Possible values:
- Consulting / System Integrator
- Academic
- Startup
- Enterprise
- Government

4. profile summary
which is a short description about this person as you search their name on the internet

You will retrieve all relevant information from the Internet to get as most completed information as possible.

Return only the JSON object. Do not include any code fences or markdown.

parameters.formDescription: Upload your name card and message (optional) here. We will get back to you soon.

parameters.content:
# OCR Business Card Reader with Thai Support â€“ Enrich & Save Contacts to CRM

This workflow demonstrates how to use Typhoon OCR + LLM to digitize business cards, enrich the details, and save them directly into Google Sheets (or any CRM). It works with Thai and English name cards and even includes an optional greeting email step.

Two versions are included:

ðŸŸ¢ Without Search API â†’ Cost-free, Typhoon-only enrichment

ðŸ”µ With Search API â†’ Adds Google Search enrichment for richer profiles (may incur cost)

Use cases: Event lead capture, sales enablement, networking database.

Powered by Typhoon â†’ [opentyphoon.ai](https://opentyphoon.ai) (free API available)

ðŸ‘‰ For step-by-step Typhoon setup, see the [official documentation](https://opentyphoon.ai/blog/en/n8n-typhoon-integration-guide)
Optional nodes to facilitate sending emails

user.name: Typhoon Team
user.bio: Typhoon is an advanced research initiative focused on developing open-source large language models (LLMs) specifically optimized for the Thai language. As a hub for cutting-edge AI innovation, Typhoon offers open-source models, datasets, tooling, and research that enable the development of tailored AI solutions for real-world use cases.

data.details:
The Edit Image node allows you to manipulate and edit images. Use this node when you want to:

- Blur an image
- Add a border to an image
- Create a new image
- Crop an image
- Composite an image on top of another
- Draw on an image
- Get information about the image
- Rotate an image
- Change the size of an image
- Shear an image along the X or Y axis
- Add text to the image
